name: accipiter-gentilis
definition: The northern goshawk is a medium-large raptor in the family Accipitridae, which also includes eagles, buzzards and harriers.
description:
It is a widespread species that inhabits many of the temperate parts of the Northern Hemisphere.

The northern goshawk is the only species in the genus Accipiter found in both Eurasia and North America.

Northern goshawks can be found in both deciduous and coniferous forests.

Also, goshawks typically require close proximity to openings in which to execute additional hunting.

The northern goshawk has relatively short, broad wings and a long tail, typical for Accipiter species and common to raptors that require maneuverability within forest habitats.

It has a relatively sizeable bill, relatively long wings, a relatively short tail, robust and fairly short legs and particularly thick toes.

Across most of the species' range, it is blue-grey above or brownish-grey with dark barring or streaking over a grey or white base color below.

Individuals that live a long life may gradually become paler as they age, manifesting in mottling and a lightening of the back from a darker shade to a bluer pale color.

Northern goshawks are carnivorous, mainly consuming birds, mammals, invertebrates, and reptiles of moderate to large size.

Individual prey items can weigh up to half the weight of the goshawk.

The content of an individual goshawks diet depends upon the environment in which that goshawk live.

The average diet consists of 21 to 59 percent mammals and 18 to 69 percent birds, with the remaining percentages being made up of reptiles and invertebrates.

Some common prey include snow-shoe hares, red squirrels, ground squirrels, spruce grouse, ruffed grouse, and blue grouse.

When courting a mate, female goshawks will attract males in the area by either performing dramatic aerial displays and vocalizing, or by perching in the nesting area and vocalizing.

Once a mate has been found, the two goshawks begin to construct or repair their nest.

Male and female goshawks typically maintain a life-long pair bond and only upon death will they seek out a new mate.

Northern goshawks normally only vocalize during courtship or the nesting season.

Adult goshawks may chatter a repeated note, varying in speed and volume based on the context.

The male calls a fast, high-pitched kew-kew-kew when delivering food or else a very different croaking guck or chup.

When calling from a perch, birds often turn their heads slowly from side to side, producing a ventriloquial effect.

facts.name: Solitary bird
facts.value: Goshawk is solitary bird except during the mating season which takes place during the spring (from March to April).

facts.name: Wingspan up to 1.27 meters
facts.value: Goshawk has a wingspan of 89 centimeters to 1.27 meters. Short and broad wings and long tail facilitate maneuvering among dense vegetation when goshawk chases its prey.

facts.name: Females are larger than males.
facts.value: Northern goshawk can reach 46 to 69 centimers in length and 0.63 to 1.4 kilograms of weight. Females are larger than males.

facts.name: Goshawk is a carnivore
facts.value: Goshawk is a carnivore (meat-eater). Its diet is based on medium or large-sized birds (such as grouse and crow), snowshoe hares and squirrels. Goshawk easily tears apart its prey thanks to curved beak and sharp claws.

facts.name: Bowl-shaped nest made of twigs
facts.value: Goshawks build bowl-shaped nest made of twigs, bark and grass high in the trees. Female lays 1 to 5 bluish-white eggs from April to May. Only female is responsible for the incubation of eggs that lasts 35 to 38 days. Male provides her with food during that period.

facts.name: Bluish-grey or brown plumage
facts.value: Upper part of the body is covered with bluish-grey or brown plumage. Neck, throat and belly are light grey or white colored. Dark horizontal lines can be seen on the breast, while black vertical lines cover the throat. Goshawks have reddish-orange eyes with white stripe above them.

facts.name: Perform impressive undulating flight
facts.value: Goshawks perform impressive undulating flight and produce gull-like calls during the mating season.

facts.name: Leave the nest 34 to 41 days after birth
facts.value: Young birds are ready to leave the nest 34 to 41 days after birth, but they depend on their parents until they reach the age of 70 to 90 days. Goshawks reach sexual maturity at the age of 2 to 3 years.

facts.name: Attack humans when have chicks
facts.value: Goshawks are very aggressive when they take care of their chicks. Female will attack all intruders (including humans) that can be found close to the nest.

facts.name: Goshawks are monogamous birds
facts.value: Goshawks are monogamous birds (one pair mates for a lifetime). One pair occupies territory of 570 to 3500 hectares during the nesting season.

facts.name: Goshawk is very persistent bird
facts.value: Goshawk is very persistent bird. It is able to chase the snowshoe hares 45 to 60 minutes until they enter open areas where goshawk can easily scoop them from the ground.

facts.name: Silently waits for the prey to appear
facts.value: Goshawk silently waits for the prey to appear and then rapidly descends toward it. Goshawk kills its prey using strong, constricted talons.

facts.name: Survive up to 19 years in the wild
facts.value: Goshawk can survive up to 19 years in the wild.

facts.name: When goshawk flies
facts.value: When goshawk flies, it combines active flying with gliding through the air.  It can reach speed of 61 miles per hour.

facts.name: Goshawk is diurnal animal
facts.value: Goshawk is diurnal animal being active during the day.

related.definition: A large eagle of the Northern Hemisphere, having dark plumage with brownish-yellow feathers on the back of the head and neck.
A North American eagle characterized by a brownish-black body and a white head and tail in the adult.
The black kite  is a medium-sized bird of prey in the family Accipitridae, which also includes many other diurnal raptors.
